title: ISO 9241 Field Validation Expedition
theme: Run a full ISO 9241-210 cycle for a public services app
overview: Students act as an embedded UX strike team helping a city services department modernize its incident-reporting portal. The labs walk through context research, requirement synthesis, interaction definition, and field validation grounded in ISO 9241-210 and ISO 9241-11.

labs.title: Lab A · Context Recon
labs.summary: Observe field conditions and convert them into ISO 9241-210 context-of-use artefacts.

labs.title: Lab B · Requirement Forge
labs.summary: Synthesize requirements and blueprint an interaction aligned with ISO 9241-112 information presentation guidance.

labs.title: Lab C · Field Validation
labs.summary: Plan and evaluate field trials using ISO 9241-11 metrics and ISO 9241-210 evaluation activities.

resources: City of Helsinki service design playbook (reference)
completionMessage: Consolidate field notes, update the service backlog, and prepare a stakeholder playback for city leadership.

challenges.title: Shadow the Field Crew
challenges.narrative: Two inspectors file pothole reports from tablets while on the street. Your job is to capture their environment, goals, and constraints to seed the design cycle.
objectives: Document context-of-use elements per ISO 9241-210 (users, tasks, equipment, environment).
Identify mismatches between the current tool and real-world needs.
Summarize findings for quick team alignment.

tasks.content: Review the field inspection transcript summarizing how inspectors juggle gloves, notes, and the tablet.
tasks.helper: Circle every time they lose signal or dexterity; those moments become requirements later.

tasks.instruction: Consult ISO 9241-210 clause 5.4 and jot the four context-of-use elements you'll need evidence for (users, tasks, equipment, environment).
tasks.helper: Write your own definition for each element — it will keep interviews focused.

tasks.instruction: Fill out the context-of-use canvas with at least two bullets per row, referencing timestamps from the transcript.
Ask the instructor (acting as inspector) clarifying questions about goals, policies, and workarounds before assumptions harden.
tasks.helper: Use the last row of the canvas to log any new risks or surprises.

tasks.instruction: Produce a one-page context brief with at least three quotes, summarizing who, what, where, and constraints.
tasks.example: Quote: 'Sun glare means I duck under trees to read maps.' — ties to environment + display contrast.

quizzes.question: Which detail belongs in the context-of-use description?
choices: Lighting conditions and gloves affecting touch input
quizzes.rationale: Environmental factors like lighting and gloves influence usability and must be captured.

quizzes.question: Why document equipment constraints early?
choices: To avoid assumptions that violate ISO 9241-210 context requirements
quizzes.rationale: Equipment constraints shape usability requirements and must be explicit per ISO 9241-210.

challenges.nextStepCue: With context captured, proceed to analyse incidents and extract user requirements.

challenges.title: Translate Field Notes into Requirements
challenges.narrative: You will transform observations into prioritized user requirements, balancing inspector needs and civic transparency goals.
objectives: Write requirement statements that tie back to observed context.
Reference ISO 9241-210 clauses when justifying priority.
Prepare a backlog slice for design.

tasks.content: Sort your context notes into three piles: pain points, opportunities, constraints.
tasks.helper: Use sticky IDs that match the context canvas so traceability stays intact.

tasks.instruction: Consult ISO 9241-210 clause 5.5 and capture the wording about traceable requirements.
tasks.helper: Translate the clause into a checklist: user, need, reason.

tasks.instruction: Write five requirement statements using the requirement sheet so each line ties to an observation and clause.
checklist: State the need as an action

tasks.instruction: Review open data policy prompts to ensure transparency and retention rules are considered before prioritizing.
tasks.helper: Note any policy constraint next to the related requirement so legal review is faster.

tasks.instruction: Prioritize requirements using the MoSCoW board, citing the ISO clause for each Must and Should.
checklist: Place each requirement ID in a column
Add clause reference for Must items

quizzes.question: Which requirement best reflects ISO 9241-210 guidance?
choices: Inspectors must capture GPS coordinates with one tap while wearing gloves
quizzes.rationale: It links user, task, and context directly, aligning with ISO guidance.

quizzes.question: Why cite ISO clauses when prioritizing requirements?
choices: To anchor discussions in human-centred design obligations
quizzes.rationale: Referencing ISO 9241-210 clarifies why a requirement matters for user wellbeing and compliance.

challenges.nextStepCue: Requirements locked? Jump into Lab B to design the incident reporting interaction.

challenges.title: Design the Incident Flow
challenges.narrative: Using requirements from Lab A, outline a responsive flow that inspectors can complete in under two minutes, even under rain.
objectives: Structure the interaction using ISO 9241-112 information presentation principles.
Specify sensory feedback that works outdoors.
Ensure the flow can degrade gracefully for offline use.

tasks.content: Review the incident wireframe reference and mark areas where inspectors struggled during recon.
tasks.helper: Note which screens need glove-friendly targets or offline cues.

tasks.instruction: Consult ISO 9241-112 clause 8 on consistency and jot naming rules before editing labels.
tasks.helper: List any terminology decisions you must align with the onboarding scenario so language stays unified.

tasks.instruction: Complete the interaction flow matrix, mapping each step to inputs, outputs, feedback cues, and offline fallbacks.
checklist: Reference ISO clause for key adjustments

tasks.instruction: Ask the instructor how inspectors currently recover from lost signals and document the workaround sequence.
tasks.helper: Add the workaround as a dedicated offline branch in your matrix.

tasks.instruction: Create a flow diagram (stickies or slides) plus a paragraph explaining how the design reduces cognitive load per ISO 9241-112.
tasks.example: Location step surfaces GPS + manual entry side-by-side, chunking decisions and adding offline banner for conformity.
checklist: Mention at least one feedback cue

quizzes.question: Which layout improves readability under glare?
choices: Large touch targets with high-contrast labels
quizzes.rationale: Large, high-contrast elements align with ISO 9241-112 for constrained environments.

quizzes.question: What feedback best signals offline capture?
choices: Explicit banner stating data is queued with timestamp
quizzes.rationale: Clear messaging keeps inspectors aware of system state, supporting conformity with expectations.

challenges.nextStepCue: Flow designed? Head into Lab C to plan and execute field validation.

challenges.title: Plan Field Trials
challenges.narrative: Before shipping, the city wants proof the tool works across districts. Design a field validation plan referencing ISO 9241-11 metrics.
objectives: Define effectiveness, efficiency, and satisfaction metrics relevant to inspectors and coordinators.
Select participant profiles and logistical considerations.
Outline data collection and analysis methods.

tasks.content: Plan to recruit six inspectors across three districts with unique network constraints; note who represents each environment.
tasks.helper: Use initials (P1–P6) with district tags so you can map them into the test matrix quickly.

tasks.instruction: Consult ISO 9241-11 clause 6 to define effectiveness, efficiency, and satisfaction metrics plus thresholds.
tasks.helper: Write at least one metric idea per dimension before opening the matrix template.

tasks.instruction: Fill out the field test matrix covering participants, scenarios, metrics, and success thresholds.
Ask the instructor/legal proxy about geo-data constraints, retention periods, and consent language.
tasks.helper: Document requirements in the compliance checklist and link to the logistics brief risk section.

tasks.instruction: Write a logistics brief summarizing schedule, roles, equipment, and risk mitigations tied to ISO metrics.
tasks.example: Day 1 (North district): focus on low-light conditions; backup hotspot assigned to coordinator.
checklist: Document mitigation for top three risks

quizzes.question: Which metric represents efficiency?
choices: Average number of taps per report
quizzes.rationale: Efficiency is about resources used; taps per report reflects interaction effort.

quizzes.question: Why include coordinators in the study?
choices: They rely on inspector data and affect context-of-use
quizzes.rationale: Coordinators are secondary users whose needs influence effectiveness and satisfaction.

challenges.nextStepCue: Plan approved? Execute the trial and evaluate outcomes in the final challenge.

challenges.title: Evaluate and Report
challenges.narrative: Field trials generated data and inspector anecdotes. You must analyze results and recommend go/no-go actions.
objectives: Map findings to ISO 9241-210 evaluation activity outputs.

tasks.content: Review the field validation data pack with completion times, error counts, SUS, and quotes before synthesizing.
tasks.helper: Highlight any metric breaching the thresholds you set in Challenge 4.

tasks.instruction: Consult ISO 9241-210 clause 5.7 and list what evaluation outputs you must provide (findings, recommendations, iteration needs).
tasks.helper: Write the evaluation loop (results → decision → iteration) at the top of your notes.

tasks.instruction: Populate the evaluation findings board with insight, ISO reference, impact, and decision/owner.
checklist: One insight per metric or quote

tasks.instruction: Ask the instructor about city hall political considerations (timelines, union feedback, press).
tasks.helper: Log constraints in the risk section so leadership sees awareness of external factors.

tasks.instruction: Prepare a three-section executive report summarizing metrics, recommendation, and next steps.
tasks.example: Headline: Only 2/6 inspectors hit efficiency target; Go decision deferred pending offline sync fixes.

quizzes.question: A 20% error rate exceeds your threshold. What should you do per ISO 9241-210?
choices: Document findings and iterate the design solution
quizzes.rationale: The evaluation activity feeds back into design for iteration before rollout.

quizzes.question: Which statement best communicates satisfaction results?
choices: Average SUS = 78 (target 80), main complaints: glare and latency
quizzes.rationale: It cites quantitative data plus qualitative drivers, aligning with ISO 9241-11 reporting style.

challenges.nextStepCue: Share the findings with stakeholders and archive artefacts for the next cohort.
